Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Experiments with Bose-Einstein Condensates II
Award.AbstractNarration:
Topological structures are central to many different branches of physics, at a variety of different energy and length scales. Quantized vortices, for example, express the rotational properties of a superfluid system; and, cosmologically, Dirac monopoles have long been sought in the magnetic field since evidence for their existence has implications for the quantization of charge. Here, several experimental aspects of topological structures in the pristine and highly controllable context of dilute-gas Bose-Einstein condensates are explored. The dynamics of small clusters of interacting quantized vortices and their response to changing environmental conditions, including temperature and the strength of the interatomic interactions, are explored using real-time imaging techniques under development as a central part of the project. More exotic topological structures in spinor condensates are also sought for study, including merons (two-component vortex "molecules") and Dirac monopoles.

Research on topological structures engages fundamental problems in basic physics and the nature of the world. Progress toward answering these questions contributes to the understanding of increasingly complex phenomena and ultimately to its application to problems of significance. Here, one might envision a study of superfluid rotation as leading to the creation of more sensitive rotation detectors. Of more direct and immediate benefit is the emphasis on education and training of undergraduates of diverse backgrounds in the performance of cutting-edge research in physics. This training takes place much earlier than is typical of research universities. The participating students then become active members of the next generation of scientists and citizens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A droplet of ultracold matter is perhaps a surprising place to study certain aspects of high-energy particle physics. Over the past four years the research supported by this grant has been doing just that, examining analogues of fundamental particle-like phenomena that exist in this unusual medium. The key to the importance of the experiments is that the analogue systems obey essentially the same set of equations as do the real-world systems, and thus the study of one set affords insight into the other.

Several new particle analogues have been created and studied. Two of the experiments have examined analogues of magnetic monopoles - particles possessing only a single north or south pole, which have not yet been convincingly observed in nature but might explain aspects of charged particles. One of the experiments simulated the interaction of a quantum-mechanical charged particle, such as an electron, with a magnetic monopole --- an interaction first studied theoretically by Paul Dirac in 1931. The comparable real-world experiment is far beyond our present experimental capabilities, and thus we gain valuable insight by studying the analogous physics. The other experiment created a quantum-mechanical monopole analogue directly within the fluid. A supplemental theoretical work then demonstrated how the latter monopole analogue decays into the former as a result of atomic interactions in the ultracold medium. These experiments were the first to create and study these particle-like analogues.

Another analogue of a fundamental particle studied in this research project is the knot soliton. Knots are familiar objects in the physical world, appearing in contexts ranging from art to technology. Although it can be tiny and particle-like, a knot soliton is not a point particle, like an electron. It is, instead, a highly organized extended object that consists of an infinite number of linked rings. Knot solitons behave like persistent particles because these rings cannot easily be untied or unlinked. The mathematics associated with knot solitons was first studied by Heinz Hopf in 1931, and it now plays a central role in the mathematical study of shapes, a subfield known as topology. It is also fundamental to many different branches of physics. One of the project's experiments successfully created a quantum knot soliton for the first time. The experiment resolved the linked rings and laid the groundwork for future studies of its stability and dynamics.

The project also provided funding to train a postdoctoral researcher, a graduate student, and several undergraduate students, helping to ensure the high quality of the next generation of researchers in physics. It also provided critical equipment for continuing studies of these quirky particle-like phenomena.
